title: Newcastle vs Manchester United live updates : Premier League start time , streaming info , predictions and team news
body_text:
Advertisement
How Newcastle beat Manchester United 2-0 to move into third place in Premier League
Summary
Newcastle United have beaten Manchester United 2-0 at St James' Park, lifting them to third place in the Premier League table.
After a first half that saw the hosts on top in everything but the score, they broke through in the 65th minute through Joe Willock.
Callum Wilson added the second in the 88th minute to put the result out of reach.
Analysing Newcastle 2-0 Manchester United
Chris Waugh and Dan Sheldon have broken down a potentially pivotal result at St James’ Park, taking a look at:
- St James’ Park relishing a feisty encounter
- Erik ten Hag’s midfield set-up causing Manchester United problems
- Mercurial Saint-Maximin and third-time-luck Willock making their presence felt
- The Wout Weghorst experiment indicative of Manchester United’s woes
- Where this result leave both sides in terms of finishing in the top four this season
Luke Shaw: 'It's not acceptable'
"Not a good enough performance. I feel like every time I speak after bad games, I'm always honest. I think us as a team, we have to be honest.
"I do think Newcastle are a very good side but I don't think they won the game on quality today, I think they won it on passion, desire, hunger and attitude. They clearly had higher motivation then we had and that can't be possible.
"I feel like I say the same things every time we lose, like I said, it's not acceptable. We know that. It was a massive game today and they wanted it more and at Manchester United that can't be possible."
Ten Hag needs to take responsibility for himself as well
I’m surprised by Erik ten Hag’s comments today. I think he has to acknowledge his selection and subs if he wants to criticise intangibles like passion and desire in the way he has.
Ten Hag: They wanted to win more than us
Erik ten Hag was not pleased with his side's performance:
Breakthrough performance
Newcastle United have beaten Manchester United in the Premier League for the first time since October 2019, having failed to win their previous six matches in this fixture (D2 L4).
Shots fired
Newcastle's social media team having a bit of a dig at Erik ten Hag's pre-match complaints about their gamesmanship:
Callum Wilson: 'Draws aren’t going to be enough'
"To have a few weeks out of the team, all you can do is put yourself forward. Nobody, especially strikers, wants to be on the bench so it’s great to have an impact.
"It was important that we tried to carry our momentum from before the international break. Draws aren’t going to be enough at the moment if we’re to achieve what we want to achieve."
Dan Burn: 'As Newcastle fans we’ve always disliked Man United'
"That was really special - as Newcastle fans we’ve always disliked Man United so it was good to get the win. Just to have the extra emotion in me when I play at home is great - maybe it comes out a bit too much some times.
"That was a big result today and puts us level on points with them, but we’ve got a really big week this week with three away games."
Eddie Howe: 'A big moment to go above Man United'
"It feels a big moment to go above Man United, we haven’t beaten the teams above us enough. We put it all together today in a great performance and the lads were really motivated for obvious reasons.
"It’s an incredible place to manage a football team - it’s a truly passionate football city and the atmosphere at home and away games is second to none. I really love the people and I hope we can bring them success."
Updated top-six table
Newcastle leapfrog Manchester United.
Unpacking a massive result
Chris Waugh and Dan Sheldon have analysed a potentially pivotal result at St James’ Park, taking a look at:
- St James’ Park relishing a feisty encounter
- Erik ten Hag’s midfield set-up causing Manchester United problems
- Mercurial Saint-Maximin and third-time-luck Willock making their presence felt
- The Wout Weghorst experiment indicative of Manchester United’s woes
- Where this result leave both sides in terms of finishing in the top four this season
Forget 1997, Newcastle partying like it's 1996!
Newcastle have beaten Manchester United with both teams starting the day in the Premier League’s top five places for only the second time.
The other instance was the famous 5-0 win at St James’ Park in October 1996 under Kevin Keegan.
Newcastle partying like it's 1997
Newcastle have now kept clean sheets in two consecutive Premier League matches against Manchester United for the first time since 1997, after their goalless draw at Old Trafford earlier this season.
Leaky defence away from home
Manchester United have now conceded 29 goals across their 14 league games away from home this season.
They have only conceded more away goals in a Premier League campaign once before, allowing 35 last season; a worrying trend.
Manchester United are fading
Really concerning performance by Manchester United.
They have collected 12 points from their past nine Premier League games, failing to score in the last three - the first time they've failed to do so in three straight league games since February 2020.
Sorely missing Casemiro
Manchester United have lost four of their eight Premier League games without Casemiro this season, compared to three of 19 when he has played.
Saint-Maximin's impact
Allan Saint-Maximin was everywhere today:
Massive result for Newcastle
Absolutely monumental and deserved victory for Newcastle, who make it three wins on the bounce and move up to third, ahead of Manchester United on goal difference.
There was wasted first-half chances, but Joe Willock and second-half substitute Callum Wilson delivered the win.
Massive.
Video of Wilson goal's - US readers
